essay:div.essay:p: A DIRECTORY OF SOCIETIES AND ORGANIZATIONS IN GREAT BRITAIN CONCERNED WITH THE STUDY OF INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS compiled by STEPHEN A. HEALD t. IffiAl WITH AN INTRODUCTION by SIR WILLIAM H. BEVERIDGE K.C.B., LL.D., B.C.L. DIRECTOR, LONDON SCHOOL OF ECONOMICS; CHAIRMAN, BRITISH CO-ORDINATING COMMITTEE FOR INTERNATIONAL STUDIES Published under the joint auspices of THE ROYAL INSTITUTE OF INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS and the INFORMATION SERVICE ON INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS CHATHAM HOUSE, 10 ST. essay:div.essay:p: nations. The study of international relations is a subject above all others in which constant contact between the various institutions concerned with it is essential. At the London Conference such contact was begun by the presence round a table of their repre¬ sentatives : agreements were arrived at for carrying it on, and finally it was decided that, in order to ensure its continuity, each country should form a National Committee to act as liaison between its own institutions and those

gift-doc:document-metadata.meta:publication-title: A Directory of Societies and Organizations in Great Britain Concerned with the Study of International Affairs

essay:div.essay:p: may not know where to turn for their materials. The work of the Royal Institute and the Information Service in compiling this very complete record deserves the gratitude of all who are interested in the furtherance of International Studies. W. H. Beveridge, Chairman, British Co-ordinating Committee for International Studies. October 1929.

gift-doc:document-metadata.meta:publication-title: A Directory of Societies and Organizations in Great Britain Concerned with the Study of International Affairs

essay:div.essay:p: PREFACE The present directory aims at presenting, in what it is hoped will prove a convenient form for reference, a directory of the societies and organizations in Great Britain which are concerned with international affairs, either as a primary or subsidiary object of study, or with the relations between Great Britain and other countries. ..... For the purposes of this directory, which is intended for general reference, it has been considered unnecessary to dis¬ tinguish between societies which study international affairs from a detached scientific point of view and those which do not. A distinction, however, has been made under the heading "The Study of International Affairs in General" between academic and non-academic bodies. In order to avoid too many sub-sections
